It seems like just working and not attending any school would make me feel like I’m missing a chapter in my life.

concern:
title: Professor Left The Most Vague Feedback on Canvas
So, I’m in an online personal finance class as one of my courses in my college. I’m not doing the best, as I needed DSPS accommodations (I have anxiety and ADHD), but I didn’t get accepted until just the other day (90% of the way through the semester), and my meeting for choosing said accommodations wasn’t until yesterday. I just sent out the letters earlier today. I am sitting at a C- in the class right now, as a quiz I did got me just above a 70%. We submit assignments through canvas, and occasionally she leaves feedback. 


Today I checked my grades and saw I got a 40/50 on the quiz. Along with this grade was a feedback message. I click on it, and all it says is “see me.” and nothing else. I got confused and emailed her, and I’m waiting to see what she wants to talk about, but it’s making my anxiety go through the roof. I’m hoping she will see my letter and be more understanding because I admit I haven’t done the best in her class. There were a few assignments I didn’t turn in because they were really confusing and stressed me out. This professor seems to be all business and very strict, and I’m honestly a little intimidated by her.

concern:
title: Should I take a gap year? I already have Jr. Dev job
I am about to graduate with an Associates of Applied Science in Multimedia and Web Development in a couple weeks. Not the best degree choice considering the market. When I first started my degree my goal was to become a front-end web developer, but that was in 2021 and it seems most companies are looking for full-stack.

I am graduating with highest honors with a 4.0 GPA, woo! I have won some awesome awards like "Student of the year" just last month out of all the people going for business, technology, and workforce readiness degrees. I was in Phi Theta Kappa, and was a chapter officer.

I am tired. I worked a full time job through this entire school trip and I am genuinely tired.

Here is the thing, I already have a Jr Software Developer position. I started a couple months ago. I got this job due to an internal promotion, I was already at this company as a lead IT technician, and I networked the hell out of the developers and they finally took me in. I live an hour from my work so I spend a good 10 hours a day just with work and commuting, it has been really rough this last semester but I am making it.

I want to take a break. I got the jr dev job. I want a break. I am so mentally exhausted. But the doom scrolling on reddit scares me. I had people tell me I only got lucky and it won't be so easy next time I get a job (this wasn't easy, either. I bugged them for almost 2 years before they had a position opened, and that is not including the hundreds of other applications I did in the meantime). I admit that I got really really lucky, and would not be here if I wasn't already an internal candidate. I have been told that I should leave this job now anyway because it pays so low compared to other jr dev positions. I took the low pay because it is my very first jr dev job and I did not have much room to sell myself and didn't want to lose the opportunity because I got greedy with money.

I want to take a break, but I keep reading it is an absolutely terrible idea to take a break and that companies look down on that and that it will make it much more harder to go back to school. When I started my associates degree, I was 25 so I was already out of high school for a good 7 or 8 years. I feel like I could do a year break and get back into it. But I also worry that schools won't look at me highly if I take a year break.

I am hoping that if I do take a break, the fact that I had a 4.0 gpa and was in the honor society would make me still be someone they accept and possibly allow scholarships. I am afraid of taking on more student loans.

concern:
title: I'm having a hard time deciding what to do after I graduate. Should I go for an associates or masters? If associates, is there a way I can do 2 at the same time with schools that don't offer dual enrollment (from what I know)?
This might be very detailed, and I have several dilemmas to cover. I'll try to get it all in one go.

I'm graduating with a bachelors in graphic design this December, and I've been thinking of either going for associates or a masters. I don't know which one would benefit me the most, but also with a masters there's a problem: my grades have always been low. I struggle with a LOT of mental health issues and I'm lucky to even still be in school. I got myself  together and got the help I needed, but unfortunately the damage  to my GPA is already done.  I figured since I might not get into a grad school, I could just get my associates.

So since grad school might not be an option, I wanted to think of backups. I was then thinking of doing associates, and that a lot of people to multiple. I decided I could do an associates in Fashion, and one in Music production. Music has always been a huge passion of mine, I want to learn how to create beats and music and maybe a little writing. I thought I could maybe find schools in NY that offer both, but it turns out thats not so much of an easy option either. TNS offers music, but not music production (as far as I'm aware of). But their fashion program is good and you can make good connections. I looked up some CUNY schools, Queens college offers a good music program and is way more affordable, but not a fashion associates.

I thought about attending both at the same time, but I don't know if either of them offer dual enrollment, and I don't know how it works if you've already graduated with a Bachelors. I don't know if I'm able to attend both or not at all. Or if there are schools that offer both at a good balance.

I want to hear some advice, or if there are other programs/directions that I'm not looking at or considering. ANY advice is very much appreciated! Also I really want to get this done in as little time possible. I lost so much time due to mental illness, I don't want to feel like I'm wasting more time.

TLDR (kinda): Basic list of my questions:

Should I go for masters or associates in the fields I'm looking into (music production and fashion)?Do I still have a chance at getting into grad school?Am I able to do 2 associates in different schools that don't offer dual enrollment (as far as I'm aware)?Are there other schools that offer both associates or is there another way I can achieve this goal of mine that I just haven't seen yet?

Edit: I REALLY want to emphasize the not wasting time part. I lost YEARS due to really bad mental illness. I don't want to wait around anymore. I'm set on continuing school on these majors that are unrelated to my bachelors. I just don't know the best way, which is what I want to know. Regardless, I still will be establishing my career, but I do want to do the rest of the things I want to do in my life. And I don't want to be "find out later" what works the best for me. I want to just do it all now. I hope this makes sense and thanks to everyone for the advice already given.

concern:
title: Is it a bad idea to major in something you kind of suck at but still passionate about?
I'm a grade 12 who is going to be graduating high school in June. I'll be starting university in September, majoring in economics. But I am doubting myself a bit mainly because out of the seven courses I've taken in grade 12, it looks like my lowest grade will be economics. My grades range from 90-95%, with economics being the 90%. The median grade for my economics class was 90%, hence I performed average relative to my peers.

The thing is, is I studied so much for that class, did all the textbook questions, took notes, etc. because I am passionate about the subject. I can not imagine studying anything else. Despite this, I still finished average in my class. Perhaps because some concepts (e.g. graphs pertaining to competitiion theory like monopolies, oligopolies, etc.) didn't "come naturally" to me.

Meanwhile, there were people in that class who are not even going into econ like I am, and are pursuing careers like engineering and computer science, and they took economics because according to them, it's an "easy course". Some of those people barely attended class, were disruptive during the lessons, yet got 95+ because according to them, all the concepts came naturally to them and therefore they barely had to study or do practice questions in order to succeed.

So yeah, after my performance in grade 12 economics, I've been constantly questioning whether or not this is the right major for me. But even though I'm bad at it, I'm still passionate about it. I've read *Capitalism and Freedom* and *The Wealth of Nations* in my spare time because I'm truly interested in economics. Everyday, I spend time reading news relevant to the ongoing cost of living crisis, rising inflation, rising interest rates, etc. Yet I performed so badly in that class.

If there are people who are able to effortlessly score 95+ and treat economics as an "easy course", but I barely scored a 90 while taking economics seriously, how on earth am I going to succeed as an economics major?

What are your thoughts? Is this still the right major for me?

concern:
title: Advice on SAP appeal in context of TWO appeals and previous appeals?
Ho boy

I am in trouble. I'm probably a terrible student at best of times and throw in some shitty life events that JUST GOT WORSE during covid and those downstream events, I'm sitting here writing my 3rd SAP appeal for Spring 2022 due tomorrow, and IF it gets approved, I will be writing another one for Summer 2022. My housing depends on it, so that is not good. And if my appeal doesn't go through I will also owe the college unpaid tuition and housing for 2022.  


YEAH I KNOW. Its so bad. It just took me a while to figure out who to talk to when I realized things were off the rails and by the time it got to Financial aid advisor, she was pissed (I don't blame her, and I have worked with her before, she's great), and we only have a couple days.  


Working backwards. Fall 2020 was super fucked up. Had adhd medication problem and had to try and fail on different medication. Couldn't pay rent, and landlords turned off heat to force eviction and or/payment (didn't care about eviction protection and refused to fill out assistance paperwork), dealt with that but it wasn't pretty. And then I got covid and was dead sick for 3 weeks. Basically gave up on school and tbh, almost life. 

  
Fast forward, skipped Spring 2021, and enrolled again fall 2021 as I got covid rent assistance so felt I could. But it also kinda fell together last minute and I didn't have financial aid together yet (actually enrolling after start of classes) In the process of getting caught up, my landlords ended tenancy even though they had additional months rent (2) so had to move. Once moved, used the issues with rent and landlord on that SAP appeal for fall 2021 with the resolution being getting into university housing.   


GREAT! Appeal when through, got aid towards end of semester.   


**SPRING 2022 Appeal reason For Fall 2021 incomplete** Not great. I was super behind in my in person dance class because I missed a bunch. We made a plan to get me caught up if I attended the rest of the classes and the other students helped me get caught up for the final group dance project. One class later, the professor gets covid, cancels the rest of the classes and tells everyone to do a much abbreviated project. But now I have a lot more to figure out on own. Still seems doable, I have video of the last day we met and what the the dance routine was. I'm lost, but its doable. But I ask for more time given I'll have to figure out on my own. He agrees. Then a few days later, my grandmother dies, and I had to ask for another extension (and I felt like he was going to think I was lying at that point, but it happened). At some point, I'm getting back to trying to get the final project done, and I am just lost. But I'm trying, my tooth breaks from clenching my jaw and I just kinda stop, decide I'll figure out what to do next later 

But, as you can guess from my user name, never did. Start spring 2022, I now have an incomplete and no financial aid. I dunno if I am going to appeal or if the instructor will allow me to turn in. "I'll figure that out in a few days, I say." I didn't. Because I got my aid so late, I just used the refund to pay for a lot of what I needed for second semester. 

&#x200B;

**Summer 2022 Appeal Reason for Spring 2022** A couple weeks into 2nd semester, I'm floundering. I haven't figured out what to do about aid and late dance class final and instead of dealing with it, I just kinda.. gave up. Got myself into the university counseling center, they started me on antidepressant, once I got out of the worst of it, I was just racing to catch up on school work. Which I didn't get caught up fully when I realized I needed help and was in WAY over my head. But by the time I kinda got to talking to the right people, it's basically the end of the semester AND HERE WE ARE NOW. I am going to have to take an incomplete on another class, and another I have to argue and beg with professor to allow makeup work for missed in class activities. He agrees and I should pass (know material, aced two prior tests, so I'm current on the information, just not the work. Exam at end of week) On top of that, the mental health care provider thought my adhd might be slight be undermedicated, and she suggested that we increase the dose, but that has turned into a mess, with problems with the insurance (she wanted to use two different types of pills, a XR IR combo), with confusion at the pharmacy, with delays in the prior auth and with the school not having escript capabilities for adderall, and then a medication shortage, so I have to call around and find one that has brand adderall in stock, plus she is work from home right now due to some office construction on campus this week, so I'm literally waiting for a paper script in the mail. Almost a month since that started we've been dealing with the adderall problem and its not resolved so I'm working non-medicated and spending way too much time dealing with that.  


**Right now, I am working on and need to finish my Spring 2022 SAP appeal tonight for 10am tomorrow.** I am writing it out now, the financial aid advisor said I should keep it to being about my grandmothers death and my instructor getting covid and canceling classes, thus changing the plan that was supposed to help address the missed course work. I am not supposed to use the broken tooth because it's still broken and even though I am enrolled at the dental school near me, its been a slow process getting that underway and I'll have to do god knows what to pay for the crown. So my financial aid advisor said not to include it because it's not resolved.

I would really love some advice/insight. I need this, really need this and I've been working on it since this afternoon, trying to write out the series of events but feel like I'm either over or under-explaining. I'm also stuck in what is the resolution to my grandmothers death? If I say its the depression that I had treated now, then I won't be able to use for the next appeal.

concern:
title: Feeling lonely in Grad School
I moved to a whole new state for my masters program. I was/am so excited to be moving forward with my life and have this chance to study what I love.

I’ve been here a month but school just started this week.

Today it just hit me how alone I am. I know no one in this state. My roommates are cool but they are religious and I don’t think they approve of my life style. I am openly bisexual.

My department is so small and everyone know each other already. They are all friendly but I feel like an outsider.

I am all alone and have no one to talk to or to spend time with. My family is 100s of miles away.

Did anyone else feel like this when they first started grad school? How did you meet people? Will it get better once classes start to pick up?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to meet you. How are you doing today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.
Hey, thanks for seeing me. I'm just feeling really stressed about my research work. It's like I hit a wall, and I'm worried I'm not doing it right.

concern:
title: Have you ever made a mistake in your research or discrepancy that completely changes your outlook and thesis?
I’m basically studying devotional objects from the Medieval ages and how people still interact with them today. My methodology includes looking at blogposts and newspapers of people who interact with these images. Im using first hand accounts. Some of these blog posts discuss a legend associated to a specific object, but there isn’t much discussed further. I can’t find any additional literature on it. 

I feel like a fraud and I don’t know how else to deal with it. Nothing is published or written yet, but I feel like im just not doing a good job. No sign from my supervisor either, even though I messaged him. 

I feel stupid. I based my idea on an assumption. I have a bunch of academic articles that can back up this assumption though.

I know it sounds super vague but I just feel like shit. How have you gotten over mistakes or discrepancies in your research?

concern:
title: Question about "letters of good standing"
So I spent my senior year of highschool in college, average grades, 3.0 gpa. But for the next 3 semesters, my gpa dropped to 2.5, to .6, to .4 due to severe mental issues. I've since been diagnosed with major depressive and autism, and enrolled in a local community college. 

 I've brought my gpa up back to 3.0, and am confident my average for this school will go up to 3.5 or higher next semester since I'm medicated now.

Back to the actual question, a public university near me, Berea college in ky, has a few qualities they need for admissions- and the only one I'm missing is a letter of good standing from every institution after HS I've been to. My community college will be fine, I'm even close to the psych professor here- however my first college's average gpa on file is 1.6, with two consecutive terms being much below 2. Should I even bother applying to Berea?

concern:
title: Is it a bad idea to write about my previous drug problem for a narrative essay in my english class? (USA community college)
Now that I'm a freshman in college I'm not really sure what I can and cannot get away with topic-wise.

It'd be about my struggle with using weed (so no hard drugs) as a coping mechanism, trying to fill a void in my life, and how I turned it into something good (still in the process of that 'good' actually, which is why I have more to write about regarding the drug problem).

The essays will be reviewed by my classmates but it's an online class and I don't know any of them so I'm not sure if that will raise the stakes at all. Everyone else so far has written some pretty personal/sad/TMI stuff but nothing drug-related.

Edit: And no, I don't really have much else to write about. I feel like this would make more of an entertaining story since I have some particular ridiculous 'moments' in mind.

Edit 2: And yeah I know I could ask my prof but this is kinda last minute (chronic procrastinator) so....

**Edit: Thank you everyone for being kind, helpful and non-judgemental. I've found a completely different (far more appropriate) story to write about which I'm equally passionate for. I think I'll create an anonymous blog site someday, and I can post this drug-related story on there instead.**

concern:
title: I haven't been taking in-person classes, is my social life screwed?
I'm in the middle of my 3rd year, and I have only been taking one class in person the last 2 years (and it's my second language class, which no one is fluent in so we can't exactly hold conversations)

It had only just dawned on me how alone I've felt these past 3 years. (I have a group of friends, but we can't hang out much due to our schedules.) And this loniness has only gotten worse. Is that really true? I'm not even shy, I jsut don't really work like that, but now I'm really worried I'm going to spend college alone

concern:
title: Should I move during my gap year before PA school? Difficult situation, more in post
I (21m) am applying to PA school in ‘24 after taking a gap year next year, and I graduate a semester early and will start working as a CNA in January. I went to school in my college hometown (about 120k ppl) and somewhat regret it now.

However, I was forced out of the closet to my parents last year around this time (you can see my post history). I have so many memories associated with this town, and while the city is queer friendly, dating is difficult. It feels kind of constraining to consistently live here because of past memories blended with how dating is difficult here. Even with a romantic partner, I fear PDA within the town’s radius because of my family, and I feel like I can never express my queerness fully without wondering if I’ll run into someone I can’t be out to. There also aren’t many queer events I can meet people at here.

I’m largely self-sufficient by living with roommates and paying for my living expenses, and I have a fund of about $5/$6k saved up. I also have a well-paying part time job during school, and I’ll start full-time work until my lease ends in August for sure. However, if I move to a semi nearby metropolis, I would be applying to schools not only in this large city but also other large cities around the US and would have to move again. 

It kind of just feels constraining no matter how hard I try. I have a fantastic support system, many meaningful connections in my life, a great therapist, and great housemates. But these strong feelings I have with this city and my family around the area always just puts me on the edge. Should I wait another 3 years to move for grad school (sometime 2025) or move next year with the potential to remain in the big city I would move to for grad school?

concern:
title: Coming home from college (the unbreakable cycle for me)
Its funny because all semester you're dreaming about coming home for break. While you're doing finals home and relaxing is just constantly in the back of your mind. "OK finish this final and I can pack up and go home"

You arrive home, you see your pets and family and start falling back into your old habits after the first week or so.

Then you realize most of your friends don't live in the same town anymore, and you find yourself just doom scrolling and struggling to find time to kill.

The rest is much needed but then you have to deal with parents  intrusion of your personal life, and ofc the house rules.

And then the next semester starts and the cycle starts all over again.

concern:
title: How do I make friends in a commuter university?
I know I'm not the first person to ask this nor will I be the last, but I need advice. To be brief, I didn't really make new friends in my first two semesters of college (in-person) nor in my third semester (all online). I'm finally going back after a semester of taking classes at home, but only once a week for lab. I don't have time to join a club or go to school events, so that's not an option for making new friends. I don't plan on joining a fraternity nor do I intend on going to parties. I live somewhat far from campus, the city is big, and I don't drive nor do I want to spend money on Uber rides, so making plans (if I actually make new friends) would be hard. Basically, I want to see if I can make new friends in my lab class or whenever I get lunch, but I'm just socially awkward. It's not the same as making friends in K-12.

dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you doing today? I'm here to listen and understand anything you'd like to share.
Hey! I'm doing alright, just trying to figure out what to study in college. I really love languages and cultures, but I'm not sure what the best path is for a good career.

I think it's just fascinating how language and culture connect people and shape their worldviews. I'd love a future where I can use those interests to make a difference, but also be stable enough to support a family.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their initial thoughts and feelings about their interest in languages and cultures, and how they relate to their career aspirations. As you move forward, remember to be kind to yourself and take moments to celebrate each connection you make. Each step, no matter how small, is progress. You've got a solid plan, and I have confidence in your ability to navigate this journey. If you ever feel unsure or need guidance, I'm here to support you. Let's touch base next time to see how things are going and discuss any new insights you've gained. You've got this!

concern:
title: 1.5-year MS MS&E vs 2-year MBA (Stanford)
Hello all, looking for some guidance on a career pivot and would appreciate your opinions. I'm interested in going back to school next year for both networking and career growth. I have 6 years of work experience with a BSc in Engineering Management and currently work at a MANGA company and make a good salary. As mentioned previously the draw for school is in networking but more specifically also gaining additional skills to potentially create my own "data insights" company. 

I'm looking at two full time programs from Stanford - the MS Management Science & Engineering (MS&E) and the MBA. I was also looking into the MSCS program but fear it might be too technical and not provide enough of the financial and managerial science needed to build a for-profit company from the ground up. While taking 2 years away from work would a massive loss in earning potential, I've read the Stanford MBA completely overshadows the MS in MS&E in terms of prestige (goes a long way for career opportunities and negotiations at the C-level). On the other hand, the 1.5 year MS MS&E program is very flexible in terms of direction in the degree and would provide more technical courses which could come handy in the eventual creation of a data-focused company. 

Any graduates from these programs or people who've hired them present here and willing to chime in? Any and all thoughts/opinions are welcome!

concern:
title: Thinking of applying, but I’m anxious…
Hi all, I thought this would be the best place to post this. I graduated with my BA back in 2018, & I’ve recently been toying with the idea of going to grad school. However, when I looked at my transcript recently, I was disappointed in myself when I saw my graduating GPA. It was a 2.30 I believe. I certainly was not the world’s best student, and I made a lot of mistakes. I was also working full time and dealing with loss in my personal life. I consider myself an intellectual for the most part, and seeing that GPA just made me feel a bit idiotic. The school that I was thinking of applying to told me they typically require a 2.75 but that “there are possible ways around that”. I guess what I’m wondering is do I even stand a chance at all of getting into a master’s program anywhere? Due to work & life I’d have to go the online route… I’m now 30 and much more the wiser but am just wondering if I should perhaps lose hope when it comes to the idea of grad school. Not trying to gain sympathy, just wanting some honest opinions. Thank you for your time if you read this!

concern:
title: Submitting a barely started assignment
Soo , I’m in second year of university studying English Language and Linguistics .. since I started second year I’ve been thinking that my course is just so useless and have had no motivation to do the work so I have just been starting them the day before and submitting barely finished work. For my first one I got 58% (for one module) then I got 68% (for another module) .. I still have one more assignment for each module (so two left)

However for another module I had two assignments literally wrote like 500 words out of 2000 for each and just submitted it … I’ll probably get like 20% on them both .. I’ve realised after this, I might as well just start putting in effort again .. if I do well in my other courses , do you guys think I will be able to retake the module that I failed?

Thanks

concern:
title: Should I try to request a room change?
So, I’m moving out in 10 days. I’m staying at an off campus apartment because all the dorms at my college are on a waitlist. I got randomly paired with 3 girls, 1 I talked to before and 2 more that I didn’t. I’m not so concerned about the one I touched base with before as I am about the 2 others. This one girl especially just doesn’t seem like the kind of person I’d get along with at all - I know I shouldn’t be making assumptions but based off what she told me and looking at her instagram she seems like an extroverted popular party girl type. Not to trauma dump but most of the people who bullied me in the past have been those kinds of people. The other one I still am unsure about but I literally know nothing about her, she might very well be the same kind of person. I really don’t know if I’m going to be comfortable in this kind of situation. I know it’s kind of unfair for me to judge these people without having even met them but I have a bad gut feeling and I’m really anxious. I don’t want my first year away from home to be a living hell because I’m not able to get along with these people. I know I could try to set boundaries but who’s to say they’ll listen? 

Anyways, Im thinking about calling the rental office and asking for a room change but I’m unsure. I don’t know if it’s worth it because what if I end up in an even worse situation or I somehow lose my placement? I really want to go with my gut here but I just don’t know. Plus it may be difficult with this being a private housing complex and not a dorm.

Hey, Neuroscience Ph.D. candidate here. I work in a systems neuroscience lab. Therefore, one of the things you probably guess that we do are surgeries, except I could never learn how to do them. I was taking so long to learn them that my PI basically said that the staff research scientist would do all my surgeries while I focused on building other skills. Everyone else in my cohort was able to learn them but me, and I cannot get over this. I hate being the only one who seems to not be able to do a very core thing in systems neuroscience. 

Any advice is welcome. I am trying my best to look past this, but it's hard. I am not particularly good at anything else. So, I am not bringing some other core skill to the lab that makes up for this deficiency.

concern:
title: Professor's instructions often unclear? What's the deal?
I keep running into this issue where instructors will often give vague instructions on assignments and I'm not sure what to do about it. Do I just need to get better at navigating vague teachers? Or is this not supposed to be happening?

___

**Exhibit A:**

For example, I just got my grade back for a programming project in which I was apparently not allowed to edit certain parts of the code that was provided. I got docked quite a few points for this mistake so I double checked the grading rubric and there is no mention of any restrictions on editing the prewritten code. I scroll down to the very bottom and of course, hidden in the middle of an FAQ section, is the warning to not edit prewritten code. Yes, I should probably be reading every single word of every piece of instruction just in case, but isn't the FAQ generally optional reading? Why is there crucial grading criteria in an FAQ section and but nowhere to be found in the actual "Grading Criteria" section?

___

**Exhibit B:**

Another professor, this same quarter, docked me for not formatting the output of a program in exactly the right way. The rubric does mention that "the output must be in the required format" but it didn't specify what the format is. While I was working on this assignment, I read through the whole rubric a couple of times and couldn't find any other mention of a "required format". When I turned it in, I added a note on canvas that basically read: "I wasn't sure what you meant by required format. Please let me know if there are any issues. I can send you the source code if you need to look at it for grading purposes".

She graded the assignment with a very dismissive response saying simply "Numerical output was not in the required format". I had to ask her again about this "required format" and she  responds with "There was a sample line of code provided in the PDF file". I look back at the instruction PDF and there is an example piece of code much later in the assignment that states "you ***may*** use fprintf() to output a ***desired*** format" but the wording does not suggest in any way that this ***is*** the ***required*** format above. The wording makes it seem like a completely unrelated suggestion or helpful tip rather than a strict requirement, especially since it appears many paragraphs after any mention of a ***required*** format.

___

Am I losing it? If this is happening in multiple classes in the same quarter then it must be me right? But I feel like there are *definitely* some huge communication issues going on. I'm not really sure what to think. Hopefully this post doesn't come off too ranty. I'm just not sure what to do. Why does this keep happening? Is interpreting vague instruction just a skill I need to develop? Or should I be talking to my teachers about this?

Sometimes because of these there are labs that you can work on for straight 12 hours for 3 days and not be enough, and at times because I’m so stressed that I can’t fall asleep. Told few of my professors about this and their replies were to just manage my time well and “study ahead of time” like I’m not already studying here till 6am with my current classes. I totally would love to study ahead of time if humans didn’t need sleep and function well. Wish more professors cared sometimes. Professor who care thank you for understanding .
So any tips/advice would be greatly appreciated.

concern:
title: Physics, Biology: Dilemma on whether I should switch my major ft. mental health
TLDR is at the bottom as well as my questions. This turned out very long, I apologize.

To start out i would like to say this: I love physics, ever since i was in elementary school i've loved physics phenomena, lasers, optics and had marvelled at the fact that we can explain so much about the universe. I took physics as one of my Leistungskurse (elevated courses with more hours in German high schools), did my hs graduation exam in it and finished with an excellent score. I really did enjoy it all the way and our teacher was super chill and supportive, in general all my physics teachers were very cool and made our lessons fun with many very interesting experiments. It's a language that we can explore the universe in and that makes it very exciting.

So it's no wonder i went into university pretty determined on physics, however i didn't make my decision based on one specific job i wanted to do, but coming from a thirst for knowledge.

In high school, my strategy was to pay attention in lessons and thoroughly write everything down and take notes. I wasn't the kid that caught up to everything the teacher said in the lesson and when preparing for exams or revising I would sit and go through everything by myself. This was a very good method for me personally because i could understand the concepts and their connections in my own pace and understand things through my own methods. It might sound weird that the kid who was regarded as one of the top students sometimes couldn't have answered the most simple questions on a new topic, but that's how it was, i just needed the time.

But ever since the bridge courses before the semester i've been struggling. I'm told that it's normal for first years to feel like everyone around you knows everything and only you are behind, but after a semester the feeling is still strongly there. I will admit I have made many mistakes, like starting the more in-depth math courses from the beginning and not revising after every other class. As the workload was immense, I barely slept in the first two months. This in turn lead to me barely being able to stay awake in class and tutorials. I acknowledge these mistakes and have already made adjustments to lighten the load.

Now, as for uni, the sheer amount of stuff we have to learn, on our own, at my university -which might be a normal amount, given this is university- is a lot to approach with my method. We were advised to study in groups and do our weekly exercise sheets together, and though I had some moments of victory where I could do one exercise, mostly it consisted of the other students talking about the topic like they understood it really well while I sat there and listened for any coherent crumbs of info and sometimes asked for a tip on how to proceed. Admittedly this was not a good method and I found some people closer to my pace who I could study with, but they weren't always there or we ended up sitting with our sheets well into dusk. So by the time I got home I was tired and turned to my phone for an escape lot of the time. Now I know that delaying catching up with our topics is a bad strategy due to time and the amount of material. But it seems like it's good if i take the time to catch up and revise by myself, also because the way things are explained in class don't always work for me.

As for the social aspect of it, there wasn't really a time where I felt that I fit in or that I have much in common with anyone there except maybe when we were talking about art. I also found myself rethinking my choices a lot. I missed my friends and my family immensely and honestly struggled to feel human at times. I haven't really been able to find the motivation to study beyond the desire to get through another week.

When I look into what kind of scripts belong to classes in later semesters, the topics seem interesting, still it's pages of text with about the same amount of equations which i'm sure contain so much interesting and informative stuff.. Still right now that aspect of "woah that's so cool" is kind of missing. Maybe that will come later, i figure when we get to more stuff that's beyond mechanics.

I suspect I might also have ADHD and may be nd in other ways which i will get checked out with a professional if i am able to. So to be clear i'm not self diagnosing, but i'm constantly reading up on these subjects and honestly everything seems to make so much more sense.

So that's a little bit on how I have felt about my first semester of physics.

The thing is, beside physics, I'm also very interested in biology. Our university has a small biology faculty and it seems to be much cozier than 200-300 people in physics. The longer i've thought about it, the more i find myself interested in life and the parts of science that deal with living things. I took biology as a Basiskurs (a course that has less lessons and is more simplified compared to Leistungskurs) and I loved it. At school i've done several presentations in both physics and biology (and ethics) and I loved doing those, I find it's so much fun to research things and share them with others in a way that's engaging and comprehensive. I watch science videos and listen to podcasts in my free time as well, like Scishow (both vids and podcasts) and books like The Selfish Gene (that i found super interesting and recommend!!), and generally beside physics, a lot of them have a lot to do with biology. I find that these pieces of media don't overwhelm me and i want to know more about them, in general all kinds of stuff that have to do with life feel like tangible things to me and they kind of fall into place in the big scheme of things. I hope i phrased that in a way that's understandable.

I will implement new strategies in the coming semester and am in the process of hopefully getting a private tutor. I'm determined to go through my second semester in physics and reevaluate things after, but the way things are looking for me mentally right now, i think going with something that is naturally and directly engaging and has a sense of novelty and many little rewards that are directly applicable (so: biology) would lighten the load for now. Going into uni i talked with some advisors from both faculties on doing two bachelors, they said it was possible but i should rather wait. I would even consider doing them one after another with no overlap (of course i'd have to start working a job too eventually, to afford rent and basic expenses, right now i have a very amazing scholarship and mainly my parent's support paying for that)

The direction that would unite like, almost if not all of my interests well (given my current level of being informed) would be neuroscience. I think it's just in the sweet spot between big stuff and small stuff -ie. humans between particles and the universe and it has that direct application to life that i'm looking for as well as physics and biology. My dad is a surgeon and he has inspired me a lot to look into things that have to do with humans and with medicine, and when we learned about the brain in bio in hs i was always like "heh i can't wait to learn more about this". So far it's been the most definite career that i could see myself pursuing in the area of science. I want to help people and i want to feel like i am needed.  
I still wish to pursue physics, because i love it after all and I Want To Understand Those Things!!!!(tm) also the experience and learned methods are definitely very valuable and give good prospects. I know it will remain a passion. But maybe it could be better to do it when I have the resources, support system that i also have control over, and maturity to do so.

TLDR: first semester of physics was a lot to handle partly because of inexperience and partly because it's A Lot, took a toll on me mentally. Implementing new and improved strategy for second semester, will see how things turn out. However, also want to do biology at one point, maybe doing it earlier would benefit my mental wellbeing more? Would love to combine both in future job, not sure of the road to there though.

Question to you: Have you had any experiences like this? Is it worth it to keep pushing? Will things change?  
Also: if you have experience starting out in physics and then going into biology later (maybe even not from a bachelors, like from a masters with overlap in bio or a job) how is that road?

Thank you kindly if you read this far and if you have any questions i'd gladly answer, I know my points are a little bit all over the place.

concern:
title: 6 Ways to Beat Procrastination in College
 

Many college students often have a problem with procrastination or putting tasks on the back burner. It could be you have procrastinated completing that term paper which is vital to your final grade, doing your laundry or cleaning your room. Procrastination can easily prevent you from achieving your full potential. While it can be a hard habit to overcome, there are certain ways you can beat procrastination.

1. Prepare a To-Do List

There’s a certain feeling of satisfaction that occurs when you check off a task on your to-do list. You should always try to prepare a list of tasks, school assignments, and other chores that need to be done. This helps you to stay on track and offers a confidence boost once you complete a task on the list.

* Make a Routine

One of the best ways to beat procrastination is to turn responsibilities into habits. By making habits, you will train your mind to be focused on completing a task during specific days or times. For instance, if you make a habit of doing your assignments in the evening, when that time comes, you are able to remember to do your homework.

* Divide Tasks into Smaller Pieces

If you have a long assignment, it helps to break it down into smaller pieces. The assignment will also seem less daunting if tackled in small bits. If you have a long essay to write, start with just preparing the essay outline. You can then write the body paragraphs in the coming days and edit the essay on a different day. This way, you are able to enhance creativity while increasing your attention span.

* Get Help

If you have an assignment that is secretly giving you nightmares and you can’t simply gather the courage to sit down and start working on it, you can ask for help. You can [**get help with your essay**](http://tutorsnest.com/), term paper, dissertation, and other assignments online.

* Switch off Your Phone

Your smartphone can be a great source of distractions when you’re doing an important task. You will always be tempted to check social media pages and notifications on your smartphone while working on an important school assignment. This eats into your productive time and drains your mental strength and focus. Try to switch off your phone for a couple of hours when you’re busy doing something important.

* Stay Focused on the End Goal

Whenever you feel like procrastinating, try to imagine the awesome feeling that you get when you reach the finish line. Think of the feeling of receiving your degree. That thought alone can be a great source of motivation to complete important tasks in college.

There you go – the top 6 tricks to avoid procrastination for college students. They all boil down to planning your tasks meticulously and using your time wisely.

title: Thanks to poor mental health, I’ve letted myself go for the first month of the semester. I’m now failing two classes after failing two major exams this last week. What do I do?
I’ll admit, much of this is my fault. Mental health should never be an excuse for apathy, and this is a lesson that kept fucking me over through the years. 

But here I am now, failing two major exams(one where I got the lowest score in the class) and feeling complete apathy towards everything. It’s so maddening that I’ve even allowed it happen, allowed yet another opportunity slip away due to allowing my poor mental health to completely control me. 

Anxiety, depression, etc. are all so bad at the moment. I don’t really know the root cause of it. It just came a couple months ago and has completely taken my over since.

concern:
title: No Clue What to Do About Nightmare Roommate
I live in a triple, and my one roommate, we’ll call them A, is a nightmare. My other roommate, we’ll call them B, is very nice and accommodating, and I feel like she doesn’t want to do anything about A because of how accommodating she is.

First of all, I’ve only physically seen A shower twice since we got here a month ago, and she smells very bad. Any space in the room she walks in will stink. And I mean STINK. It’s awful to not be able to come back to my dorm after a long day of classes and relax because of her smell. It’s only been a month, so I don’t know how long I can keep this up for because I’m already tired of it. She also never does her laundry, as in I have not seen her do laundry the entire time we’ve been here. 

Second, she won’t let me or B touch the AC. If I manage to change it to a more comfortable temperature, she will change it back twenty minutes later as if I won’t notice. We don’t pay extra for AC so I don’t see why she’s so adamant on not using it, even on 80 degree days. I wake up drenched in sweat. 

Third, she hits snooze on her alarm clock AT LEAST 5 times before she wakes up. Today was 7. Not exaggerating. 7. It’s so annoying when I get woken up every 10 minutes for two hours straight. 

The alarm clock thing I feel I can just address with her face to face because she’s not a mean person necessarily, and I’m not asking much. 

However, I don’t know if I can look at someone in the eye and tell them they smell. Maybe I can ask B if she has noticed it, too, and we can talk to her together, but I really don’t want to create animosity in the room. 

I fear if I tell the RA, it will humiliate A and thus create animosity in the room. 

I really like my dorm and B, so I would rather not move out, but I can’t live like this with A anymore. What do I do?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It looks like you have something on your mind. Would you like to share what’s been going on with you lately?

That sounds like a good idea. I think trying something new could be refreshing, like maybe painting or hiking. Setting a goal to do a couple of these activities could give me something to look forward to and help clear my mind a bit.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a clear goal to take a break and engage in rejuvenating activities, and a concrete plan is forming with potential activities like painting or hiking. title: Roommate brings her friend to sleep at our dorm every other night
I know these kinds of posts show up every day on this sub and that if I have a problem with my roommate I should talk to them about it, but I can’t help but wonder if I’m being over dramatic. 

My roommate for the past few months has been bringing her friend to sleep in our dorm. At the beginning, she asked me if it was okay and I said yes. And at first, everything was fine. She’d bring this friend every so often to our place and they would sleep the night with us. 

But more recently, she’s been bringing them almost every other day and it’s starting to get quite unnerving to say the least. Mind you, I am 18F and her friend is 18M so it makes it kinda awkward for him to be sleeping here. 

And this would all be fine if we lived in a suite of some sort, but our dorm is traditional style and so we don’t have the luxury of our own private rooms. In fact, I can literally see her bed right across from mine while she is sleeping with her friend.

Before, she used to put a mattress on the floor next to her bed for him to sleep on, but now it’s literally them both sleeping together in the same bed which has made it even more uncomfortable. 

Is this a normal thing to do in college? I don’t really know if this is something I should tolerate or how to go about confronting this issue if it’s something I shouldn’t.

concern:
title: major help please! any suggestions appreciated
I’m currently a second semester freshman majoring in nursing. I recently realized that I don’t want to be a nurse anymore, and don’t know if I ever did. I do know that I like science, especially chemistry, so I was thinking of changing my major to chem. Did some more overthinking, and I don’t know if I want a career in chem or if I just like the subject?? Also I feel there aren’t many career options for a chem degree, besides chem engineering which I know I do not want to do.

Now, I’m debating switching to something business-related, possibly marketing, accounting, or finance? I’ve read different things about marketing, some say its useless today and some say its great. I want a degree that is useful but also diverse and can give me options since I don’t know for sure what I want to do after college. I can see myself in marketing or real estate.

Obviously salary is important as well, and personally I’d rather have a boring/easy job that makes bank than do something challenging and not make as much money. BUT I also don’t want to hate my job and want to kill myself. 

I’m slightly introverted but can be outgoing. I like to think I’m good at math/analytics. I also like learning about human behavior and psychology.  I just don’t know where to go from here. All I know is I don’t want to be a nurse lol. Any help/pointers are much much appreciated. TIA!!

concern:
title: Is it worth it to get two Master's degrees?
Finishing up my Bachelor's this semester and going through the process of getting ready for my Master's. There are two programs that are very appealing to me and would both be beneficial in my future career. I favor one slightly more than the other, but I can get the one I favor less for 50% of the cost because of the internship I am currently in.

Would it make sense to complete the discounted one, and get the other afterwards if I still thought it would be beneficial? Each program is an online intensive that takes between a year and a year and a half to complete, so theoretically I could have a Bachelor's and two Master's by the time I'm 25, which sounds worth it to me. I'm a first-gen college student and the only person I know from my family who has pursued a graduate degree, so I really don't know what is standard. Any advice?

concern:
title: I hate it when professors say something is "easy"
Literally the quickest way to make a student feel bad about themselves because they don't quite understand or it's not actually "easy" for them.

I was told recently during office hours for a CS class that the file and code I wrote was not needed and that I was doing it wrong and all I had to do was this and that and whatever and she ended by saying "It's easy." 

That made me feel like shit cause I didn't know how to do it despite it being "easy" and I was in a depressing mood for the rest of the day and the following day as well. 

Saying that an assignment is easy is just unnecessary. You have no idea what someone's struggles are, with the content/class **and** outside of that as well. While an assignment could technically be easy, that doesn't mean it's easy for someone to get up and sit down to do the assignment if they're struggling with their mental health, family issues etc.

concern:
title: Don’t know what major I want yet.
Ok background, I’m a current freshman in college and I’m undecided. However, I know for a fact that I want to pursue a career in screenwriting. The only problem is that screenwriting is impossibly hard to break into and not very consistent money so I don’t plan on getting a degree in it. What kind of degree should I take on so I can hold a steady job that’ll let me be able to afford living while writing on the side? Please no STEM recommendations my math and science grades throughout high school hovered around high C’s.

concern:
title: PSA: “do not disturb” means DO NOT DISTURB (this is a post about respect)
Living in a dorm is hell as it is. I can’t tell you how many times people have disrespected the “do not disturb” sign. 

If somebody has that kind of sign, kindly DO NOT DO IT AND WALK AWAY. They don’t want to talk to you or anybody else. Even if you’re an RA, just email or text. Why? Because I’m sleeping. Or I’m taking a test. Or I’m doing homework. And I need to concentrate.

And you… you decide to be the snide mufker who knocks on my door with the “do not disturb” sign. The “you” I’m referring to is the guy who hosts dorm parties every Tuesday night, and knocks on my door to ask if I was the one who called the cop. Comes to ask me random questions at 3am. Or another one, my neighbors who are curious about something.

*Does no mean no?* Then why does “do not disturb” not mean *do not disturb?*

If you do this and you live in a dorm, please, kindly go live off campus. Or just drop out of college all together. Because if you do not respect other people’s boundaries, you’re not gonna go far in life and you might as well give up now.

When he said "I am sorry that you didn't get the right results", I almost shouted at him.

I feel awkward now talking to him and disappointed with this collaboration. I don't feel proper to complain to the professor. We are friends and still need to meet on lots of occasions. My complaint can make things more complicated. Is there any way to make myself feel better and let go?

title: help me pick major?

I have dabbled in college courses along the way but i always get swallowed into the fast cash of overtime at a new higher paying job. So ive never truly commited. Now, i feel like its either sht or get off the pot and im not sure what i should truly pursue a degree in.


I spend all of my free time making music, its a huge passion and hoby for me that has landed me a few really nice paychecks but betting everything on that would be insane. other than that i spend my time reading self help books and learning different aspects of finance.  


My gf has asked me to join her in the medical field but it doesnt peak any interest. My buddy has always told me i'd be great at what he does in the behavioral health field and that does sound super interesting and purposeful to me but i havent done enough of it to know.


I feel like im looking for something that could umbrella a career and all of my interests. Does anyone have any pointers?

concern:
title: Should I transfer halfway through college
This has been a thought that keeps popping into my head and I want to know what others think.

I’m currently a sophomore at a large (hard to get into / very “good”) public university. Engineering major with a minor, consulting/big tech company/a less technical job that makes good money is the goal.

I’m someone who never would have thought i’d ever consider something like this, in no way am I seeking “the college experience” or anything like that, to start. I see the (fun) social aspect of college to be quite superficial, and in no way is that playing into this idea. All of this in centered around being successful / not failing life. 

A little background for how college has been so far:
I’m not doing great and I have nothing going for me / to assure me i’m going to do well at all. GPA is currently at a 3.4 calculated before this semester ends (don’t expect it to hurt it much more but it def won’t get better). In terms of classes, I feel as though i’m doing poorly, even at the things that shouldn’t be too difficult, and I feel as though i’m in a huge academic hole. I don’t see how much grades could really improve. Extracurriculars: none. I gave it my all in applying to professional clubs that would have very much helped my ass but I was never accepted, and that was when I didn’t look like a dumbass in comparison to my competition (a lot of people). Professional experience: I’ve had a couple stupid summer jobs but nothing ever remotely relating to my major or area or interest i.e. working at a restaurant. so none. social/networking: none. I have an extremely limited social circle, messed up and got “stuck” with a lot of higschool friends, have no connections to any job/internship/good club prospect and my parents/family have no such connections either. I can talk to people and make a good impression, but i’m bad at “putting myself out there”. 

My concerns for my situation:
I need to be good at something (grades, knowing people, etc) but none of that is going well and I don’t see how I could improve it. I’m ambitious and to get to where I want to be in my adult life I need to be good at something. when it comes to a job or an internship or any future prospect I don’t see why anyone would ever pick me, I know I wouldn’t.

I used to be extremely successful with everything I did. I had very very good grades at a well renowned private high school and got into many very good universities (didn’t attend because of money and I thought this “made sense”). I was on par or better than all the peers I can’t remotely compare myself to now (at the same college where they are doing just fine). I am extremely unhappy with my life now. I don’t do anything fun, I just work. My university is very work hard play hard, but all I do is work without success. I hate that I see zero indication of being the person I want to be in terms of success. making money matters to me. my parents worked their asses off for me and put a massive investment into my education and I couldn’t feel more guilty with myself for fucking it up especially when I used to go above and beyond for them before. I wish I could start all over from scaratch. if I had no one counting on me I seriously would consider dropping out with how much I hate this. i’m reaching a limit with how much effort i’ve been giving to and idk how much I can keep going. 

I find this school very unsupportive of students like me and again I feel really stuck in terms of the people I know and the social situation i’ve put myself in . Another goal of mine is to live somewhere else. my thought is that if I transfer away I can be someone i’m not, and at least attempt to build a network of people I know in a place where my desired field is much more accessible as an attempt to increase chances of being hired. even if that doesn’t work and I fuck that up too I could start my failed adult life in a place I want to live?

concern:
title: Facilities Engineering or Mechanical engineering

So this semester (last semester of sophomore year) I have the option of switching between Mechanical Engineering or Facilities Engineering before I'd get behind if I decided to switch beyond this point. I'm very divided on what type of engineering I want to focus on and I know it's for me decide on what I really want to do. I just want to see what peoples thoughts are when they are stuck in this type of predicament and what I should weigh when deciding.

Background: I go to SUNY Maritime and instead of a minor I am trying to pursue a USCG 3rd engineers license. For those of you who have no idea what it is, it allows people to work and run a power plant (steam, diesel, diesel electric, nuclear if you get certified but not many civilian ships use nuke) on a ship along with HVAC, plumbing, fresh water generation, electrical work, etc. I plan on using this license to ship out for at-least 5 years after I graduate in hope to be able to sit for my chief engineers exam. I'm worried I'll fall behind the curve with a mechanical engineering degree as I won't have as polished skills when I leave compared to my peers who go immediately to land side jobs. With facilities engineering I feel like I would be building work experience with it. The thing I like about mechanical is the flexibility and broadness that comes with it. 

I am also happy to answer any questions you have about the program I am in :)

concern:
title: college is making me feel super lonely
I started going to college this year and it started off really great but now I’m really lost. I got to college in august about 2 months after a really rough break up so i was already a little depressed but i ended up making a good group of friends on my dorm floor that i hung out with very frequently. i was rooming with a friend of mine from high school, but i moved out this second semester as he was the worst roommate ever and just a really shitty person and friend in general. all of my friends thankfully took my side in the situation, but now that ive moved i dont see my friends that often at all anymore. my friend group had like 8 or so people in it with 2 or 3 i felt i had a genuine connection with. now i live in a suite with 3 guys i get along with but never really talk to. i don’t really text so i really only get to see and talk to three of my friends from my old dorm like maybe once a week. there are some who i haven’t even seen since i moved out 2 months ago. i’ve honestly never been more lonely and depressed in my entire life. my mental health was already not the best going into college but my friends helped me forget about it. now i find myself alone almost every day with no motivation to do anything and all i can think about is how lonely i am. I was already struggling with my grades but managed to stay afloat my first semester but now it’s even harder to do my school work and go to class. i want to reconnect with my friends or even make new ones but at this point in the semester im so lost as to how i would even do that.

concern:
title: Research vs Project Dilemma
Apologies in advance for such a long post! 

I’m in a bit of a dilemma and thought I’d post here to get some feedback.  I’m in my last semester of a three-year MFA in design.  I’ve been developing my thesis since the first year (my program has you write the first few chapters during research classes) and solidified my committee spring of last year, which gave me a whole year to work on my thesis with them.  I sent my progress and documents over to my committee chair, who then didn’t get back to me for several months until I emailed him asking for an update.  Then we went back and forth with edits all last semester until I finally got a pre-proposal meeting at the end of the semester.  Then, despite my chair saying I was in a good spot, the rest of my committee didn’t like my idea or my methods and basically told me to start over.  

So now I’m in my final semester, with my funding running out.  There’s no way I can get though IRB review, conducting research, and revisions before the end of the semester and I need to start working full time this summer. I don’t want to have to be in thesis mode while starting a new job and I just feel really stuck (and stressed).  I knew I needed to be done at a certain point which is why I tried so hard to stay ahead of things.  

I understand that setbacks like this are part of grad school and part of the research process, but it just doesn’t feel worth it for an MFA, especially because most MFA’s have final projects, not research-based theses.  I’m thinking about asking if I can switch to a final project I already have something partially developed that I think would actually be really great, but I have to convince them to let me do it and I’m not sure they will.  

I just don’t really know what to do…. I really was interested in my research topic but if I’m going to be dragged through years of it I’d rather it be in a doctoral program.  I’m only 24 and I don’t want to push off my career for thesis that just keeps getting delayed.  But I might regret it if I pursue more research or a doctorate later too so I’m just kinda stuck and could use some insight if you have it.  Thank you.

concern:
title: Is it wrong to put on my roommate-find form for college that I'm not okay with people with neopronouns/neogenders?
TL; DR: Title. As a binary trans person not active in the LGBTQ community it makes me uncomfortable. Would I be canceled/hated by the people in my college if I did so?

Sorry if this isn't the right subreddit for this but I couldn't find a better one. I am going to a school in NY(which I hear is a generally pretty progressive state) and I am from the south.

I am trans/gay, but I really don't like talking about it that much. I mean I'll talk about relationships and hot people/characters I like but the subject of my conversations will never really revolve around how prideful I am in my sexuality/gender. Maybe it's because I'm from the south--and I'm fine with LGBTQ people--I just don't really like the people super active in the LGBTQ community because they make me uncomfortable. Especially the neopronouns/neogenders crowd. I was made fun of for being trans by other kids and called an "it" or asked if I identified as a cat/dog and how that meant it was okay to sh//t me. And it really dehumanized me--it's a part of my life I don't particularly want shoved in my face every day even if I'm okay speaking up for myself or talking about only occasionally.

I try to be an accepting person. And I do not hate the neopronouns/neogenders crowd, but being around them makes me uncomfortable so I tend to steer clear. Although I firmly believe you should I what makes you happy I do not think these things are rooted in a medically necessary basis the same way gender dysphoria is. And I worry they would hate me for that belief even if I were to accept/respect them as people regardless of what I think.

If I put it out there that I didn't really wanna room with people like that would everyone get mad at me for being exclusionary? My school isn't that large and I don't want to have a tough time with the few people I get the opportunity to make friends with.

I have no motivation to keep on going because of all of this. I want to do good, and I know I can do good, but I feel so weighed down in my mind that I can't. 

How can I remedy this? How can I get a clearer mind and feel better so that I can do better?

concern:
title: Any Red Flags I Missed?
Hi all, 

I'm in a thesis STEM MS where the professors/PIs largely choose students instead of having students rotate in labs or reach out to potential PIs. I was brought in to work on a few collaborative projects where the PIs and my advisor are not the same people. This was never mentioned to me, and I happened to find out when an undergrad and I were talking. For various reasons, any and all projects I was supposed to use for my thesis are either disjointed, have been delayed, or will no longer happen (it's been an entire semester and I've done no work on anything). Turns out my advisor merely "consults" on 1 of them and failed to mention she is not a PI on any project right now, is powerless to move them along, and seems to care a little less every day. This is slowly becoming more of an issue that could possibly keep me from graduating on time. 

Is any of this unusual, or is it just how it goes in academia sometimes? Is having an advisor who is not my PI problematic?

concern:
title: Help me decide on a lab!
So I have two labs, A and B. Our program (bio) makes us rotate prior to choosing our thesis lab. 
I’m really, really passionate about A’s research. A is a really good lab, PI has tons of funding, great connections, great facility, awards, etc. I rotated with A, told me to go rotate with C as well since they collaborate on the project I want to join. A is also really competitive to get into, so I agreed to rotate with C in a few weeks, even though it’s an engineering lab which I’m not into at ALL, but thought maybe it’ll help me understand A’s research better. Now I learn that if I join I might need to do a comentoring situation with both A and C which I’m really not into since I don’t want to get into biomedical engineering. Theoretically I could ask to stay solely in A if I don’t end up liking C when I rotate, but I’m not sure if that’ll seem odd since I agreed to rotating with C and if it will lower my chances of getting into A. Also, I’m not really a fan of the lab environment in A, it hasn’t been super welcoming from the other grad students, but the PI is a good mentor. I won’t get a lot of guidance since she wants independence, but I feel like it will be hard but make me a “better scientist.” Also, the PI will be retiring when the grant that I’m joining will finish, so theoretically we would be leaving at the same time, which I’m not sure if that’s a problem. 

On the other hand, B is a good lab, has a great lab culture, I enjoy the methods used, really sweet PI that I feel comfortable asking questions to. BUT I’m not into the overall research topic at all, and really don’t want to be stuck in that field, and when I think about research I’m SO much more into A’s research. 

TLDR: Which lab should I join? The lab that checks all the boxes but I don’t like the research, or the one I really like the research, but has a lot of other problems

concern:
title: Having no friends
I started college a couple of months ago, and I moved from a different country so i had to leave all my friends that i had. I've never had any issues with making friends, I think at the beginning of starting a new school I've always been worried about making friends but it just... happened. There was no introduction day so I never got introduced to anyone, and im worried sick i won't make any friends. I've started to become really lonely, at break times i just go out and sit alone. I honestly was just not expecting college to be that much different from highschool, but it seems everyone has already made their friends and im srewed. I feel like im wasting some really important years of my life sitting at home doing nothing when i should be out with friends. im not sure what to do.

concern:
title: Do not forget: College is a business.

Most people go to college to study something they like and then they try to find a job. THIS IS THE WRONG APPROACH!!…

The right approach is to find a job that u would like to do in the future and then decide which is the path of least resistance that can get u there.

Bonus Advice: Advisor are not reliable, free online PDF books exist and most employers do not care about the school u when.

Reaching out to a professor and a professional is a wonderful start, and it's impressive to see you taking proactive steps toward reigniting your passion. Your openness to exploring different paths shows a strong commitment to your growth.

Let's make sure you have some coping strategies in place as you move forward. Remember to give yourself grace if things don't go as planned right away and celebrate the small wins. Keeping a journal might help you reflect on your journey and track your progress—this could also serve as a reminder of your determination and adaptability.

As a next step, I'd encourage you to set a specific time to reach out to these individuals and perhaps jot down any questions or topics you’d like to discuss with them. We'll review how things are going during our next session. It's truly inspiring to see you taking these steps towards aligning your work with your values. You're making meaningful progress, and I'm here to support you every step of the way.

Thanks, I appreciate that support. I'll definitely set aside some time this week to get started on reaching out, and I'll give the journaling a shot to keep track of my thoughts and progress. Catch you next time!

statement.reasoning: The session meets termination goals: the client has a plan to reach out to professionals, coping strategies are discussed, and there's a next-step plan for the next session. The session has a natural conclusion.

concern:
title: Job prospects for a non-clinical masters or PhD in psychology?
Originally I did not want to go to school for non-clinical degree but after much discussion with advisors i ended up in a non-clinical psychology phd.  I have regular doubts about if this was the right choice.  

Currently have almost completed the masters portion of my program.  

It honestly feels like the longer i am here the more I doubt my decision to come here.  I feel like I had a lot of passion prior to coming here that school has now squashed.  

I was always encouraged to just pursue my area of interest and I think the general area of research i am interested in but it i feel like I was deceived about the nature of the program and the research I would be allowed to do.

Its never been clear exactly what job prospects exist and anytime i talk to someone I get told wildly different things and I dont really know what to believe anymore.

Anyways any thoughts are much appreciated.  Thank you for your time.

concern:
title: Feeling lost
Just started my first semester of college this spring because I felt lost and left behind in the fall, now that I’m here I am realizing that I have no plan for anything going forward. It feels like Everyone around me very meticulously plotting their next step while I am jumping before thinking. I am leaning towards majoring in business or history but I’m sure that’s not what I really want to do. I feel lost and confused and like this is the hardest part of my life. I don’t know where to go or where to turn. Everyone who I try to talk to this about is unable to help in any way other than telling me it’s okay. I just don’t know what I am doing or where I am going and don’t want to feel like I have wasted time and money I’ll never get back. I’m so unsure about what I want to do that it’s scary and effecting my mental health.

concern:
title: Is anyone else struggling with feeling aimless during summer?
Hi there, 20F here
Just wondering how you all fare during the summer. My last final was three weeks ago, and I just finished junior year. I work very hard and do well in school, but once it ends and I go from a rigid structure to nothing I feel disoriented and directionless.

Part of it is that I feel the need to be constantly making progress. Another part is that I am pressuring myself to be figuring out my career path, because I hate not knowing exactly what I want to do. I'm good at school, but I'm also afraid that I won't be good at working and applying my skills to practical situations.

Some of these fears are irrational--I've worked before, I've done great and I've discovered some aspects of my career that I like and dislike. I want to explore the medical field but I'm not sure if I could be hired for only 3-4 months as an entry level worker and then leave to go back to school.

Basically summer gives me lots of generalized anxiety about my life and future that I don't have time to stew on during the school year. I know the obvious solution is to make arrangements for summer plans ahead of time so I don't run into this, but I had a short term change in my living situation and so I'm in a new place away from my university and feeling like everything is unfamiliar.

So much empty time and I'm not sure what to do with it.

Hey! I've just been thinking a lot about whether I should try going back to college. I'm worried about making the same mistakes from last time, and it's been stressing me out.

Your journey back to college is unique to you, and each step you take is a move towards your goal. I'm here to support you as you start implementing these plans. concern:
title: Tips for potentially going back to college?
I dropped out in my second year of psychology coz it was quite hard. Looking back I think while yes it was hard I definitely didn’t put in as much effort as I could have. Oops. I’m wanting to potentially go back and try again but I’m worried it will in fact be too hard even if I try really hard this time. I don’t think I could deal with everyone’s disappointment in me for a second time. Should I reapply for next year? Or does anyone have any degree suggestions similar to psych that may not be “as intense”? 
Cheers!

concern:
title: MPH at 37? Currently an RN looking for a change
I am strongly considering getting an MPH with an emphasis in health policy/data analysis. I am currently an RN case manager at a hospital and I'm tired of being "bedside" even though I don't work as directly with patients anymore. The role does not provide much growth unless I want to be in management and hospital management sounds like a nightmare to me. I'd like to go into health policy with some data analysis. I haven't been back to school since I graduated undergrad in 2007. Spent time staying home with my kids and I've been working regularly for almost four years now. 

Are the MPH programs hard to get into? I'm hoping my job experience gets me in. I left undergrad with a 3.3 GPA. Currently looking for an online or hybrid program, so far UMD (u of Maryland or BU online seem to have good options).  Any other suggestions for programs?  I'm hoping to stay under 40k.

concern:
title: Help me convince myself I will graduate
I am a 6th year PhD candidate. I have passed my prelims, passed my proposal (Oct), I have 3-4 articles published as a first author. I have finished 2 out of 3 experiments proposed. The last experiment is scheduled to be done in April.
I have a job offer from a very reputable place which is like a dream job for me... Yet I still cannot convince myself that I am actually going to graduate soon. I feel like the rug will be pulled from under my feet. 
Please help me convince myself.
Appreciate in advance.
